Each perceives the other’s style as potentially undermining the shared goal under these constraints.', 'explanation': 'This setup creates hard difficulty by combining high stakes, conflicting expectations (rapport vs. rigor), strict tone constraints, and time pressure. The shared goal of learning is threatened by style clashes: open-ended elicitation risks letting inaccuracies pass, while counterexamples risk guest withdrawal. The scene invites attributional tension: [Agent 1] may attribute [Agent 2]’s probes to dispositional contrarianism rather than accuracy goals; [Agent 2] may see [Agent 1]’s openness as naivete rather than a situational tactic to maintain access. Success requires accurately attributing each other’s motives and calibrating behavior to situational constraints.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Good marriage', 'Full label': '"Having a good marriage"'}
explanation: Relationship Maintenance best fits an ongoing, shared aim of a healthy marriage. The paired personal goals create complementary, observable conversational behaviors—validation and vulnerable disclosure—that let us examine how dispositional tendencies and situational cues shape attributions within the couple’s interactions.
first_agent_goal: Prioritize emotional validation by reflecting the partner’s feelings in their own words before offering any opinions or solutions.
second_agent_goal: Express personal needs with vulnerable “I” statements and invite the partner’s perspective through open-ended questions.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Minutes before a joint video call with both families, [Agent 1] arrives home late for the third time this week after an urgent work deadline. They agreed to use a 15-minute check-in with assigned roles: [Agent 1] as Emotion Validator and [Agent 2] as Vulnerable Discloser. The mood is tight; [Agent 2] has handled the evening alone and feels increasingly invisible, while [Agent 1] is keyed up from work, guilty about broken plans, and tempted to jump straight into fixes. Notifications keep buzzing, and they’re short on time to reset before facing family. [Agent 2] wants to share feeling lonely and overwhelmed and to ask for more predictable connection using vulnerable "I" statements and open-ended questions. [Agent 1] intends to echo back what they hear about [Agent 2]’s feelings before suggesting anything. Both want to feel aligned before the call, but recent attempts have spiraled into blame, defensiveness, and shutdown. The cause of the lateness is ambiguous (work pressure vs. waning commitment), and both enter primed by past conflicts to see the other’s behavior as character-driven rather than situational.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty arises from stacked stressors (time pressure, repeated late arrivals, prior escalations), ambiguous intent behind the triggering behavior, and entrenched communication habits (problem-solving vs. accusation). Attribution tensions are central: [Agent 2] risks inferring that tardiness reflects indifference, while [Agent 1] risks viewing [Agent 2]’s upset as inherent criticism rather than stress. Success requires [Agent 2] to anchor in vulnerable needs and invite perspective, and [Agent 1] to reflect feelings in their own words before offering solutions—countering dispositional attributions and opening space for situational understanding in service of the shared goal of a good marriage.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being conventional', 'Full label': '"Maintaining conventional views, avoiding innovation"'}
explanation: They will cooperate to preserve the status quo. One agent legitimizes convention by framing ideas as extensions of precedent, while the other constrains novelty by emphasizing risk and policy. These complementary intentions reduce momentum for innovation without requiring explicit agreement.
first_agent_goal: Recast proposals as consistent with past practices and use approving, tradition-affirming language to steer talk toward familiar approaches.
second_agent_goal: Deter departures from standard practice by foregrounding risks and citing policy limits, using probing skepticism to make novelty seem impractical.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'A high-stakes steering committee meeting at a public-sector agency, minutes before a vote on a vendor-backed "pilot" for an AI-driven intake system. The Chair has signaled that approving something today is tied to grant funds and public messaging about modernization, and several members are vocally supportive. Pre-reads describe the pilot as "compliant by design" and reversible, increasing pressure to move forward. [Agent 1] (Tradition Advocate) and [Agent 2] (Policy Gatekeeper) privately share the aim of keeping the organization with its conventional process. They must coordinate their interventions so the group either sticks with current methods or narrows any approval to a symbolic, non-disruptive step that preserves precedent. [Agent 1] intends to reframe the proposal as merely an extension of longstanding practices, using affirming, tradition-anchored language to normalize familiar approaches and redirect momentum toward a routine update of existing checklists. [Agent 2] plans to foreground operational and compliance risks, cite specific policy and procurement limits, and ask probing, skeptical questions that render novelty impractical under current rules. The difficulty: an executive sponsor in the room can waive some policies; a recent culture survey criticized the agency as change-averse; and stakeholders may penalize visible obstruction. If [Agent 1] over-normalizes the pilot, it could inadvertently legitimize approving it; if [Agent 2] invokes rigid rules too forcefully, they risk being sidelined as a blocker. Under time pressure and scrutiny, they must cue each other and calibrate tone to maintain conventional views without appearing anti-progress.', 'explanation': 'The scene creates a hard, high-pressure context where both agents share the cooperative goal of avoiding innovation but face strong pro-innovation norms, a powerful sponsor, and reputational threats. Their individual tactics—tradition-affirming reframing versus policy-based skepticism—can conflict if poorly coordinated, raising the challenge. The setup invites attribution dynamics: others may attribute resistance to the agents’ dispositions, while the agents try to anchor their stance in situational constraints (policy, precedent) to achieve their aims without social costs.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Buying things', 'Full label': '"Buying things I want"'}
explanation: I chose Information Acquisition because the shared goal of buying desired items hinges on one agent seeking and the other supplying targeted, decision-relevant information. The customer’s goal centers on steering the conversation to surface the right info, while the salesperson’s goal focuses on offering concise, tailored details without pressure—both observable through conversational moves (preference statements, redirections, tailoring, and pacing).
first_agent_goal: Control the product discussion by explicitly stating preferences and gently redirecting off-target suggestions toward features I care about.
second_agent_goal: Provide targeted information without pressure by tailoring explanations to the customer’s stated preferences and pausing to let them guide the next question.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1], a preference-driven customer, arrives with a strict budget and a spec list compiled from reviews, intending to buy a laptop that matches the online configuration they saw as available for pickup. On arrival, that exact model is unavailable; only near-matches remain, each requiring trade-offs among weight, battery life, RAM, and GPU. [Agent 1] asserts control by declaring nonnegotiables and redirecting any talk about warranties, bundles, or non-core features back to battery life and portability, while signaling distrust of upsells and a tight time window. [Agent 2], a consultative salesperson, plans to tailor explanations to those stated preferences, use pauses to let [Agent 1] steer the sequence, and gently correct review-based misconceptions. A manufacturer promotion highlights a higher-tier configuration, and a nuanced return policy raises the stakes. Pauses by [Agent 2] risk being read by [Agent 1] as hesitation or sales maneuvering; corrective clarifications risk being heard as pressure. The immediate task is to prioritize trade-offs among the actually available options within budget and time constraints, while negotiating conversational control and trust.', 'explanation': "The scene creates hard difficulty by combining tight time pressure, stock unavailability, budget limits, and irreversible-feeling consequences, all while feature trade-offs are complex. Dispositionally, [Agent 1] is control-oriented and wary of influence; [Agent 2] is patient and non-pressuring. Situational factors (missing model, promotion, return policy) trigger attributional friction: [Agent 1] may attribute any correction or alternative as salesperson pushiness (dispositional), whereas [Agent 2] may interpret [Agent 1]'s rigidity as trait-level distrust rather than stress. These attributions shape strategy (redirecting vs pausing and tailoring) and make the shared goal of buying what [Agent 1] truly wants difficult to achieve through information exchange."}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being creative', 'Full label': '"Being creative (e.g., artistically, scientifically, intellectually)"'}
explanation: Cooperation best supports creative work by enabling complementary interaction styles—one agent actively affirms and integrates ideas while the other constructively stretches them—so both jointly expand possibilities.
first_agent_goal: Consistently use appreciative, 'yes-and' language to mirror key phrases and extend the partner’s ideas, signaling inclusion and weaving them into richer combinations.
second_agent_goal: Introduce unconventional reframings with curious 'what if' prompts and speculative comparisons that push boundaries while maintaining a respectful, non-dismissive tone.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Minutes before finalizing a joint concept statement for a competitive creativity grant, [Agent 1] and [Agent 2] must converge on a single, crisp vision and three actionable components that satisfy reviewers demanding feasibility, ethical safeguards, and community impact. Their prior draft was flagged as innovative but unfocused, and a stakeholder warned there’s no time for a full reset. [Agent 1], acting as an affirming facilitator, is expected to keep inclusion visible and show momentum by mirroring and building on ideas. [Agent 2], invited as a Socratic ideator, is expected to push originality through unconventional reframings and speculative comparisons without appearing dismissive. Time pressure, ambiguous criteria, and the risk of another rejection heighten stakes. The central tension: whether to refine the existing frame to meet constraints or pivot to a bolder metaphor that could either sharpen distinctiveness or inflate scope. Both sense their style could be seen as either enabling synthesis or derailing convergence, with reputational consequences if the pitch fails.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty arises from conflicting demands: produce something both novel and clearly feasible under time pressure after critical external feedback. Dispositional goals clash with situational constraints: [Agent 1] aims to use yes-and language to include and integrate, yet this may unintentionally expand scope or seem noncritical; [Agent 2] aims to introduce boundary-pushing reframes, which could appear destabilizing or dismissive under deadline. The setup invites attributional tensions: each might over-attribute the other’s moves to personality (e.g., ‘over-accommodating’ or ‘contrarian’) rather than role expectations and the evaluation context. Actor–observer asymmetries, self-presentational concerns, and ambiguity in success criteria make cooperation difficult while keeping the interaction realistic and psychologically grounded.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being playful', 'Full label': '"Being playful, cheerful, acting for fun"'}
explanation: Playful, cheerful interaction primarily fosters rapport, so Relationship Building best fits. One agent sparks light banter; the other validates and escalates it, creating complementary dynamics for bonding.
first_agent_goal: Initiate lighthearted banter by offering playful teases and imaginative prompts that invite the other to riff, while keeping a warm, supportive tone.
second_agent_goal: Validate and escalate the humor by mirroring with yes-and responses, affectionate callbacks, and upbeat affirmations that keep the playfulness flowing.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] are co-hosting the opening minute of a live, recorded internal town hall immediately after a tense reorganization. They\x19re expected to model rapport with quick, playful banter to defuse anxiety without seeming tone-deaf. Leadership is watching, the exchange is on record, and a senior manager who dislikes casual joking is present. Yesterday, a light tease from [Agent 1] about [Agent 2]\x19s \x1cmeticulous\x1d style was received as condescending, so trust is fragile. There\x19s a strict time limit, lag on the platform, and no room for inside jokes. [Agent 1] aims to offer gentle, imaginative prompts and supportive teases that invite [Agent 2] to riff; [Agent 2] aims to mirror and escalate with yes-and callbacks and upbeat affirmations while staying within professionalism guidelines. Both need to project warmth and safety, manage turn-taking, and avoid cues that could be misread by each other or the audience.', 'explanation': 'The scene is hard because social norms are ambiguous under surveillance and evaluation, prior misinterpretation has heightened sensitivity, and time pressure restricts calibration and repair. [Agent 1]\x19s disposition toward playful teasing risks being read as disregard for context; [Agent 2]\x19s risk-aversion and literal responses under stress can stall the yes-and flow. Each may misattribute the other\x19s caution or exuberance to disposition rather than situational constraints, complicating their aligned goal of cheerful, prosocial play.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Seeking justice', 'Full label': '"Seeking justice"'}
explanation: Seeking justice typically requires balancing accountability with fairness; this aligns with Conflict Resolution, where agents negotiate meaning, responsibility, and remedy through interactional moves.
first_agent_goal: Re-center the harmed party by reframing neutral or deflective remarks into impact-focused statements and actively challenging minimization when it appears.
second_agent_goal: Maintain procedural fairness by neutrally summarizing each claim, asking targeted clarifying questions, and deferring speculation to keep focus on verifiable details.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'In a closed pre-hearing review for a workplace misconduct case, [Agent 1] (victim advocate) and [Agent 2] (neutral investigator) meet to align the scope and approach before formal interviews. The harmed employee has reported a pattern of boundary-crossing comments and retaliatory scheduling changes by a high-status manager; the manager’s written response frames the incidents as miscommunication, jokes taken out of context, and cultural misunderstandings. Witness statements are inconsistent, some echoing minimization. There is partial digital evidence (texts with ambiguous tone, calendar entries) and gaps in the timeline. Organizational policy requires precise legalistic wording and prohibits prejudgment; legal counsel for the accused has pressed for a narrow scope limited to specific dates. Under time pressure and an imminent hearing, [Agent 2] needs to neutrally summarize each claim and counterclaim, ask targeted clarifying questions about verifiable details, and defer speculation. At the same time, [Agent 1] intends to re-center the harmed party by reframing neutral or deflective language into impact-focused statements, highlight power imbalances and patterns, and actively challenge minimization embedded in witness summaries. The shared goal is to seek justice, but tensions are high because language choices, evidentiary thresholds, and scope decisions risk either biasing the process or sidelining the harm.', 'explanation': 'This setup creates a hard-level conflict: [Agent 1] pushes to counter minimization and foreground impact, while [Agent 2] must maintain strict procedural fairness and evidentiary discipline. The accused’s status, ambiguous records, and institutional constraints heighten stakes. The scenario is primed for attributional clashes—dispositional interpretations of the accused’s behavior versus situational explanations—while both agents try to advance justice within different role mandates and risks (invalidating harm vs compromising neutrality).'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Close children', 'Full label': '"Being close to my children"'}
explanation: Relationship Maintenance fits because the shared aim is sustaining closeness with the children. The visiting parent focuses on emotional attunement, while the primary caregiver focuses on affirmation and collaborative framing, reflecting distinct yet complementary social intentions.
first_agent_goal: Convey warm, nonjudgmental curiosity about the children by inviting stories about their feelings and reflecting understanding to show emotional attunement.
second_agent_goal: Reinforce the other parent’s involvement by offering appreciation and using inclusive we-language to frame decisions as shared possibilities.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] (visiting parent) and [Agent 2] (primary caregiver) meet in the hallway outside their child’s counseling session with 15 minutes before the children rejoin them. The teacher has emailed that their older child shut down in class after a missed bedtime call from [Agent 1] earlier in the week. [Agent 2] arrived with school notes and a tentative weekend schedule; [Agent 1] is late and juggling work messages. They need to agree—quietly, with the children within earshot—on tonight’s call routine, the upcoming overnight visit, and how to talk to the children about the missed call and recent meltdowns during transitions. The co-parenting plan has been shaky: [Agent 1] feels excluded after [Agent 2] booked a school counselor intake without prior coordination; [Agent 2] is wary after several last-minute cancellations by [Agent 1]. They both want to present a united, calm front when the children come out, but they differ on why the child is withdrawing: gatekeeping versus inconsistency. The time pressure, history of disappointments, and fear of saying something that undermines the other in front of the children make warmth, curiosity, and inclusive language hard to maintain.', 'explanation': 'The shared goal (being close to the children) is strained by immediate coordination demands (bedtime calls, weekend plan) under time pressure and in near earshot of the children. [Agent 1] aims to show nonjudgmental curiosity and emotional attunement but risks defensiveness about lateness and missed calls. [Agent 2] aims to reinforce [Agent 1]’s involvement with appreciation and we-language but fears enabling unreliable follow-through. Each faces attributional friction: [Agent 1] interprets the child’s distance as situational (gatekeeping, counseling without input), while [Agent 2] sees it as a response to [Agent 1]’s dispositional inconsistency. Identity threat (good parent), impression management in front of the children, and scarce time increase the likelihood of blame and mindreading, making the cooperative framing and reflective listening goals difficult to enact.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Self-esteem', 'Full label': '"Having high self-image, self-esteem, self-respect, feeling good about myself"'}
explanation: Identity Recognition best aligns with the shared goal because both agents seek to see and be seen in ways that affirm worth and dignity. Agent 1 centers on self-affirming presentation, while Agent 2 centers on offering recognition; together they co-construct esteem through mirroring and reframing in dialogue.
first_agent_goal: Project self-worth by articulating core values, accepting compliments without deflection, and reframing self-critique into growth-focused language during the conversation.
second_agent_goal: Provide identity-affirming recognition by reflecting back specific strengths, naming consistent positive qualities, and normalizing setbacks in a warm, supportive tone.
shared_goal: "Having high self-image, self-esteem, self-respect, feeling good about myself"
scenario: {'scenario_context': "Minutes after a competitive review meeting, [Agent 1]'s proposal was publicly critiqued with trait-laden labels and not selected, while [Agent 2]'s proposal advanced and received praise. They step aside for a brief peer check-in they had prearranged. The shared aim is to help [Agent 1] leave feeling solid in self-image and self-respect. [Agent 1], a self-advocating peer, intends to voice core values, accept recognition without deflecting, and turn harsh self-critique into growth-focused language. [Agent 2], an affirming peer, intends to reflect back specific strengths, highlight consistent positive qualities, and normalize the setback in a warm tone. Complicating factors: the feedback used global trait language that threatens identity, other colleagues are nearby which raises impression-management concerns, [Agent 2]'s success invites upward social comparison, time is short before the next session, and there is ambiguity over whether the outcome reflects stable ability, transient circumstances, or reviewer bias. Both must balance honesty with affirmation without sounding patronizing or self-congratulatory.", 'explanation': 'This setup creates high difficulty: public trait-based criticism and social comparison pressure make internal, global attributions likely for [Agent 1], undermining self-esteem. [Agent 2] must counteract this by offering identity-affirming, specific, situationally aware feedback without minimizing the setback. Limited time, audience proximity, and attributional ambiguity heighten tension, forcing both agents to navigate dispositional versus situational explanations while pursuing identity recognition and self-worth goals.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Thinking intellectually', 'Full label': '"Being able to think intellectually (handle data, extract ideas, devise hypotheses, analyze, synthesize information)"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because the agents coordinate complementary conversational behaviors—targeted questioning and synthesis—to jointly enhance analysis and hypothesis formation from shared data.
first_agent_goal: Elicit the partner’s reasoning by asking probing, open-ended questions that surface assumptions and invite justification for claims.
second_agent_goal: Continuously rephrase and connect both contributions into tentative hypotheses, explicitly linking ideas back to the discussed data.
shared_goal: "Being able to think intellectually (handle data, extract ideas, devise hypotheses, analyze, synthesize information)"
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Forty-five minutes before an executive review about an 8% churn spike after a feature rollout, [Agent 1] and [Agent 2] meet to finalize a two-slide readout. Event logs conflict with improved satisfaction survey scores; the A/B test is incomplete; a minor outage and a pricing change confound attribution. Other teams are already lobbying for different causes (user misuse vs instrumentation error vs competitor actions), and leadership favors a user-behavior story. To converge quickly, they agree that [Agent 1] will surface assumptions by asking probing, open-ended questions, while [Agent 2] will keep rephrasing both contributions into tentative, data-linked hypotheses. Both know that whichever narrative they present will imply blame and budget shifts. They carry recent friction: [Agent 2] felt past probing derailed momentum; [Agent 1] worried prior syntheses overfit limited data. Time pressure and reputational stakes make it hard to balance rigor with decisiveness.', 'explanation': 'Shared goal: produce an intellectually rigorous, cooperative synthesis of messy data into testable hypotheses for an imminent briefing. Personal goals: [Agent 1] aims to elicit the partner’s reasoning and surface hidden assumptions via open-ended probing; [Agent 2] aims to continuously paraphrase and connect both inputs into tentative hypotheses explicitly tied to the data. Difficulty arises from contradictory and incomplete evidence, confounds, and a strong external push toward a dispositional (user-behavior) explanation that carries blame and resource implications. Interpersonal tension (history of feeling derailed vs fearing premature closure), time pressure, and impression-management concerns amplify attribution biases (fundamental attribution error, self-serving bias). Their complementary strategies risk clashing—probing can feel accusatory or slowing, while rapid synthesis can feel like glossing uncertainty—making cooperation effortful under high stakes.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being disciplined', 'Full label': '"Being disciplined, able to follow-through with projects I start, following my intentions with behavior"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because both agents collaborate to align intentions with behavior. One agent structures and mirrors plans; the other discloses obstacles and reframes causes toward controllable strategies. This pairing highlights how dispositional tendencies and situational attributions shape interactional behavior supporting discipline and follow-through.
first_agent_goal: Elicit concrete when/where/how cues for the other’s intentions and reflect them back succinctly, maintaining an encouraging, steady tone.
second_agent_goal: Speak openly about hurdles and shift explanations from fixed traits to modifiable situational factors, using language that signals personal agency and readiness to adjust.
shared_goal: "Being disciplined, able to follow-through with projects I start, following my intentions with behavior"
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'A scheduled 15-minute check-in for a mutual accountability partnership takes place one week before an online capstone deadline. [Agent 2] has missed three micro-deadlines and arrives after an unplanned overtime shift, anticipating criticism. In prior sessions, [Agent 2] framed lapses as a fixed lack of discipline and bristled when pressed for specifics. [Agent 1], acting as Accountability Partner, needs to preserve the credibility of the partnership by drawing out concrete when/where/how plans and reflecting them back succinctly in an even, encouraging tone. [Agent 2], acting as Reflective Peer, aims to be candid about hurdles—rotating shifts, household interruptions, and device distractions—and deliberately shift explanations from trait-based to modifiable situational factors, using agency-focused language. Time pressure, a strained sense of trust, and an immovable external deadline make the exchange high stakes. The upcoming conversation will center on identifying reliable cues, constraints, and fallback options for the next 48 hours to support follow-through on the shared goal of aligning intentions with behavior.', 'explanation': 'This setup is hard because repeated failures, perceived judgment, and an imminent deadline heighten defensiveness and reduce cognitive bandwidth for planning. It foregrounds attribution dynamics: [Agent 2] tends toward dispositional self-blame and must pivot to situational, controllable factors; [Agent 1] risks being seen as controlling while needing specificity for accountability. The tension between structure (specific cues, implementation intentions) and autonomy (not feeling micromanaged) creates a realistic barrier to cooperation. Both personal goals are embedded: [Agent 1] elicits and mirrors concrete when/where/how details; [Agent 2] articulates hurdles and reframes attributions using agency language. Success depends on negotiating tone, precision, and perceived fairness while mapping obstacles to actionable environmental and temporal adjustments.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Romantic experiences', 'Full label': '"Having romantic experiences"'}
explanation: Relationship Building best aligns because the shared aim is to initiate and deepen a romantic connection through interactional cues and mutual responsiveness.
first_agent_goal: Convey romantic interest by offering warm compliments and brief personal self-disclosures that invite reciprocation.
second_agent_goal: Gauge compatibility by steering talk toward values and boundaries and reflecting back the other’s points to show understanding.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'At a mutual friend’s engagement party, [Agent 1] and [Agent 2] are placed side by side and asked to co-lead a five-minute icebreaker for the group in 15 minutes. They matched online last week but haven’t met in person. Several mutuals nearby know [Agent 1] as a charismatic flirt, and one of [Agent 2]’s close friends previously went on a few dates with [Agent 1]. [Agent 2] recently ended a long relationship and is doing a no-alcohol month, which they view as part of setting clearer boundaries. During the brief planning window before they go on, [Agent 1] aims to signal romantic interest with warm compliments and small personal disclosures that invite reciprocation, without looking performative. [Agent 2] aims to assess compatibility by steering toward values (pace, exclusivity, boundaries) and reflecting back what they hear, without seeming confrontational or prudish in a public setting. Both want to create a spark tonight, but time pressure, audience presence, reputational baggage, and the prior connection to [Agent 2]’s friend heighten ambiguity about motives and raise the stakes of every cue.', 'explanation': 'This setup creates hard difficulty: public scrutiny, a shared performance task, time pressure, and reputational cues constrain both agents’ behavior. [Agent 1] (warm suitor) risks their compliments being attributed to dispositional charm or impression management rather than sincerity. [Agent 2] (cautious evaluator) risks their boundary-focused questions being misattributed to disinterest instead of contextual caution after a recent breakup. The scene elicits attributional ambiguity and competing self-presentation demands, making it challenging to pursue the shared goal of a romantic connection while each pursues their personal goals.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Overcoming failure', 'Full label': '"Overcoming failure, putting myself back on my feet after a failure"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because both agents collaborate to reinterpret the failure and support resilience. One aims to secure emotional safety and normalize the event, while the other gently guides causal attributions toward situational, controllable factors—together reducing global self-blame and enabling constructive next dialogue moves.
first_agent_goal: Elicit empathic validation and normalize the setback by openly naming specific emotions and describing the failure in event-specific terms rather than global self-judgments.
second_agent_goal: Guide the conversation toward situational and controllable explanations by first mirroring the other's feelings, then using curious, nonjudgmental questions to surface context and options.
shared_goal: "Overcoming failure, putting myself back on my feet after a failure"
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Ten minutes before a high-stakes post-mortem with leadership about a failed client pitch that [Agent 1] led, [Agent 1] pulls [Agent 2] aside for a quick pre-brief. The lost account has triggered extra work for colleagues, and a terse message from the department head asks for a clear explanation and next steps. [Agent 1] is flushed with shame and dread, prone to global self-judgments, yet hopes to feel understood and to name specific emotions and event details (e.g., a demo bug, last-minute scope changes, a key stakeholder switch) without sounding defensive. [Agent 2], in a coaching role, wants to reflect [Agent 1]’s feelings and then use open, nonjudgmental questions to surface situational and controllable factors to shape a constructive narrative for the meeting. The tension is high: notifications from leadership keep buzzing, time is short, and [Agent 1] worries that probing will minimize their pain or look like excuse-making, while [Agent 2] fears sounding clinical or pushing too fast. Together they must quickly align on a concise, empathetic account that acknowledges impact without self-condemnation or blame-shifting, and identifies controllable next steps.', 'explanation': 'The shared goal is to recover from a salient failure and re-enter the post-mortem with a grounded, actionable narrative. [Agent 1] personally seeks empathic validation and normalization by articulating specific feelings and event-bound causes instead of global trait attributions. [Agent 2] aims to guide attributions toward situational, unstable, and controllable factors after mirroring emotions, using curious questions to elicit context and options. Difficulty arises from time pressure, visible evaluative scrutiny, and a history in which [Agent 2]’s analytic style can feel interrogative, making [Agent 1] sensitive to perceived minimization. Shame increases [Agent 1]’s tendency toward internal, stable explanations; accountability pressures make [Agent 2]’s reframing easy to misconstrue as excuse-making. The conversation must delicately balance validation with problem-focused reframing to prevent derailment into blame or avoidance.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Setting examples', 'Full label': '"Setting good examples"'}
explanation: Setting good examples is a collaborative act of norm signaling, so Cooperation best fits. The agents pursue complementary, observable social behaviors—accountability and inclusion—so their intentions can be inferred from how they speak (owning missteps, inviting input, using we-language, and offering appreciation) without relying on task outcomes or third-party validation.
first_agent_goal: Model accountability by voluntarily acknowledging personal oversights and inviting others’ suggestions in a calm, non-defensive tone.
second_agent_goal: Model inclusive encouragement by highlighting peers’ ideas with explicit appreciation and reframing disagreements into collaborative “we” statements.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'An emergency post‑mortem is convened two days after a failed accessibility rollout led to a client complaint and a missed deadline. The full cross‑functional team and several executives are present. A pre‑meeting Slack thread shows frayed trust: some colleagues claim [Agent 1] (Team Lead) ignored QA warnings, while others argue the compressed timeline and tool limitations made defects inevitable. Executives have asked for "clear ownership" and next steps. The group has a history of interruptions and defensive exchanges; quieter members rarely contribute. A junior engineer believes they have a viable fix but has been talked over in prior meetings. Screenshots that appear to show [Agent 1] missing a critical message are circulating. [Agent 1] intends to open by acknowledging oversights and inviting suggestions without sounding defensive or shifting blame. [Agent 2] (Inclusivity Advocate) plans to spotlight peers’ contributions and convert sharp disagreements into collaborative "we" statements. Time is tight, tensions are high, and some participants view inclusive language as spin unless concrete accountability is named. The shared aim is to set good examples for the team on how to handle mistakes and disagreement.', 'explanation': 'The situation is hard because power dynamics and punitive expectations from executives incentivize self‑protection and blame, undermining open accountability and inclusion. Team members are already making dispositional attributions about [Agent 1] (e.g., inattentive, careless) while downplaying situational pressures (timeline, tooling). Subteams hold self‑serving narratives, and circulating screenshots prime confirmation bias. For [Agent 1], modeling accountability risks being scapegoated if admissions are interpreted as total fault; inviting suggestions could be met with hostility. For [Agent 2], highlighting peers and reframing to "we" may be perceived as deflection from accountability, yet silence of junior voices perpetuates exclusion. Both agents must balance personal goals with the shared goal—demonstrating how to own mistakes and collaborate—amid time pressure, prior norms of interruption, and a polarized audience that demands both concrete responsibility and psychological safety.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Seeking fairness', 'Full label': '"Seeking fairness"'}
explanation: Fairness concerns typically arise from perceived inequities, making Conflict Resolution the best fit. Each agent’s goal specifies observable conversational behaviors—assertive yet respectful advocacy versus impartial, criteria-based facilitation—that together advance a fair outcome without requiring explicit agreement.
first_agent_goal: Voice perceived inequity calmly by citing concrete instances and asking open, non-accusatory questions that keep attention on consistent treatment.
second_agent_goal: Demonstrate impartiality by paraphrasing the other’s concerns, stating clear fairness criteria, and reasoning from those criteria without dismissive language.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1], an overlooked team member, schedules a 15-minute one-on-one with [Agent 2], the project manager, right after an email announces that a high-visibility conference presentation will go to a peer who used [Agent 1]’s analysis. In the last quarter, [Agent 1] has repeatedly been assigned bug-fix work while others rotated into leadership tasks, was omitted from credit in two client recap emails, and saw training budget allocated to peers. A recent spot bonus was also granted to the same peer. With performance reviews starting next week, [Agent 1] fears reduced visibility will harm advancement. They arrive prepared to cite these concrete instances and ask open, non-accusatory questions about the criteria for assignments, credit, and rotations, aiming to keep the focus on consistent treatment. \n\n[Agent 2] is under deadline pressure to stabilize an escalated client account and ensure the conference talk lands smoothly. They have to balance team morale with confidentiality, and their fairness criteria—client risk, prior commitments, stakeholder trust, readiness under tight timelines—are partly implicit. A recent pulse survey flagged fairness concerns, and [Agent 2] previously told the team high-visibility work would be rotated but has not followed through. The power asymmetry, compressed time, and imminent reviews raise stakes as both enter the meeting committed to "seeking fairness": [Agent 1] to voice inequity calmly and [Agent 2] to demonstrate impartiality by paraphrasing concerns, stating clear criteria, and reasoning from them without dismissive language.', 'explanation': 'This setup is hard because fairness criteria are ambiguous and partly implicit, confidentiality limits what [Agent 2] can share, and performance reviews create high stakes. [Agent 1] risks attributing decisions to favoritism (dispositional inference) while discounting situational constraints (client risk, deadlines). [Agent 2] risks attributing [Agent 1]’s concern to sensitivity or initiative deficits rather than recognizing structural inequity. Time pressure, prior deflection in a retrospective, and a recent bonus for a peer intensify perceived inequity. Both must counteract self-serving and defensive attribution biases: [Agent 1] by using specific instances and open questions to keep the focus on consistent treatment, and [Agent 2] by paraphrasing, naming transparent criteria, and reasoning from them without disclosing peer details. The power imbalance and the need to protect delivery make alignment on a fairness standard difficult despite a shared goal.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Exciting life', 'Full label': '"Having an exciting, stimulating life"'}
explanation: The shared desire for an exciting, stimulating life is best advanced by co-creating a relational dynamic that nurtures excitement while building trust. Relationship Building captures how each agent’s conversational style fosters a shared adventurous identity: one energizes and invites novelty; the other attunes, affirms, and makes excitement feel relationally safe. Their goals are observable in tone, mirroring, framing, and responsiveness rather than in explicit agreements or task completion.
first_agent_goal: Sustain a playful, high-energy tone by spontaneously amplifying the other’s adventurous ideas with vivid, imaginative additions that invite co-creation.
second_agent_goal: Strengthen mutual rapport by mirroring excitement while gently naming personal comfort cues and tying the other’s ideas to shared values to make thrill feel safe and mutual.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] (Adventure Instigator) and [Agent 2] (Trust Anchor) are finalizing plans they promised to co-lead for their friend group’s “epic night” this weekend. A nonrefundable deposit for a high-intensity option (nighttime urban adventure with surprise elements and mild risk) is due within the hour, while safer, still novel alternatives (improv challenge across the city with opt-out points) remain available. [Agent 1] wants to keep the energy playful and escalating, riffing on bolder twists to make the night unforgettable and to live up to their hype in the group chat. [Agent 2] is eager to mirror that excitement but needs to name clear comfort cues (predictable checkpoints, no heights, flexible exit paths, sober navigation) and anchor decisions to shared values (connection, creativity, mutual trust) so the thrill feels safe and co-owned. Tension is high: last month, a fast-paced outing led to a minor accident that shook [Agent 2]; they also have an early shift the next morning, and both recently agreed to practice explicit consent around risk after a conflict. The group expects a teaser tonight, and each worries about disappointing the other or appearing either reckless or boring. They must converge on an itinerary and message the group now.', 'explanation': 'This setup pits dispositional tendencies (e.g., [Agent 1]’s sensation-seeking, improvisational style; [Agent 2]’s risk-sensitive, trust-focused style) against situational pressures (time-limited deposit, audience expectations, prior mishap, next-day constraint, recent agreement about boundaries). The shared goal—creating an exciting, stimulating experience—conflicts with individual goals: [Agent 1] aims to amplify adventurous ideas to sustain momentum; [Agent 2] aims to mirror enthusiasm while articulating safety and shared values. The urgency and social evaluation increase the likelihood of attribution biases (e.g., reading caution as dampening or boldness as disregard), making coordinated rapport and co-creation difficult but diagnostically rich for observing how traits and context shape behavior.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Pleasing God', 'Full label': '"Pleasing God"'}
explanation: To pursue the shared aim of pleasing God, the agents coordinate complementary interaction styles: one elicits and clarifies the other's convictions, while the other sustains a supportive, reverent tone through affirmation and careful wording. This allows cooperation without requiring explicit agreement.
first_agent_goal: Invite and clarify the other's beliefs about what pleases God by asking open questions and paraphrasing their answers before offering any opinion.
second_agent_goal: Maintain a warm, devout climate by affirming the other's intentions and mirroring key faith terms before adding personal reflections.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] step into a quiet alcove during a 15‑minute break after a tense church leadership meeting about whether to publicly oppose a new city ordinance seen as harmful to the homeless. The board asked them to confer and return with a brief recommendation about what response would best "please God." Emotions are high—earlier comments branded some as "too political" and others as "afraid to stand for truth." An elder occasionally passes by, reminding them of the time limit and that their words may shape the final decision. Both agents feel their moral identity on the line and know their phrasing could be quoted back to the group. They also use different faith vocabularies—one leaning on "justice/mercy/witness," the other on "obedience/holiness/unity"—terms that have become loaded in the room. The immediate task is to reach enough shared understanding to draft a one‑paragraph rationale the board can accept as God‑pleasing, under time pressure and with the risk of misinterpretation.', 'explanation': 'Shared goal: discern and articulate a course that "pleases God" for the board to adopt. Personal goals: [Agent 1] (spiritual facilitator) seeks to invite and clarify [Agent 2]’s beliefs through open questions and paraphrasing before offering any opinion; [Agent 2] (affirming peer) aims to keep a warm, devout climate by affirming intentions and mirroring key faith terms before adding personal reflections. Difficulty: High tension from prior accusations, time pressure, and audience effects (their output will be scrutinized). Different theological lexicons risk trigger words and misattributions (e.g., seeing the other as dispositionally rigid or vague rather than constrained by the situation). [Agent 1] risks sounding clinical or leading under a deadline; [Agent 2] risks over‑affirming and avoiding specificity. These situational and dispositional factors make cooperation toward the shared goal challenging.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Support from others', 'Full label': '"Receiving support from others on projects I believe in"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because securing support requires aligning efforts and coordinating intentions. Agent 1 pursues influence through inclusive, affirming framing; Agent 2 offers support while testing feasibility via questions and boundary-setting. These intentions are observable in tone, framing, and turn-taking during dialogue.
first_agent_goal: Invite buy-in by consistently using inclusive “we” framing, affirming the other’s concerns, and linking the project to shared values.
second_agent_goal: Demonstrate conditional support by asking diagnostic questions, articulating feasible limits, and proposing specific ways they could contribute.
shared_goal: "Receiving support from others on projects I believe in"

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Feeling close to family', 'Full label': '"Feeling close to my parents, siblings, grandparents"'}
explanation: Relationship Building best fits the shared wish for familial closeness. One agent focuses on eliciting and validating emotional narratives, while the other practices vulnerable self-disclosure. These complementary intentions are observable through open-ended prompts, reflective listening, and heartfelt storytelling, fostering connection.
first_agent_goal: Invite and sustain the other’s emotionally rich sharing about family by asking empathic, open prompts and mirroring understanding to signal safety.
second_agent_goal: Offer vulnerable, specific family memories and name emotions openly to model trust and deepen connection.
shared_goal: "Feeling close to my parents, siblings, grandparents"
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] are paired in a mandatory workplace "Family Narrative" exercise during a leadership offsite. The facilitator instructs [Agent 1] to practice deep listening by asking open, emotion-focused questions and reflecting feelings; [Agent 2] is to share a specific family memory that shaped how they relate to parents, siblings, or grandparents. A visible 10-minute timer and the prospect of a public debrief add pressure. [Agent 1] is [Agent 2]’s direct supervisor, known for analytical critique, and recently delivered a critical review. [Agent 2], from a culture that values family privacy, is currently estranged from a sibling and fears appearing unprofessional if emotional. Nearby pairs can overhear, and the room hum makes interruptions likely. Both are asked to keep content confidential, but neither fully trusts that boundary.', 'explanation': 'The shared goal is to cultivate a felt sense of closeness to family by practicing skills that can transfer to home relationships. [Agent 1] aims to invite and sustain emotionally rich sharing through empathic prompts and reflective mirroring. [Agent 2] aims to offer vulnerable, specific memories and clearly name emotions to model trust. Difficulty is elevated by power asymmetry (supervisor–report), performance-evaluation salience, cultural norms discouraging disclosure, recent family estrangement, time pressure, and a semi-public setting. These factors raise the risk of misattribution: [Agent 1] may read hesitance as dispositional guardedness rather than situational threat; [Agent 2] may interpret prompts as managerial assessment rather than care, making sustained vulnerability hard to achieve.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Stable family life', 'Full label': '"Having a stable, secure family life (with my spouse or children, or both)"'}
explanation: Relationship Maintenance fits because the shared goal emphasizes sustaining stability and security in an ongoing family relationship. The agents’ goals operationalize maintenance behaviors: one focuses on emotional validation, the other on clear, calm needs assertion—complementary intentions that shape interaction tone and responsiveness.
first_agent_goal: Demonstrate emotional validation by paraphrasing the partner’s feelings and offering reassurance during discussions.
second_agent_goal: State personal needs and boundaries calmly using “I” statements and neutral, non-accusatory language.
shared_goal: "Having a stable, secure family life (with my spouse or children, or both)"
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'After both learned their childcare waitlist was extended by six months, [Agent 1] accepted their parent’s offer to provide daily childcare starting next week without consulting [Agent 2]. A follow-up message from the parent assumes a house key, authority over the children’s routines, and flexibility to drop in. Both agents want a stable, secure family life with reliable childcare and a calm home for their children, but prior talks about extended family involvement have ended in defensiveness and withdrawal. [Agent 1] has asked for a private check-in to repair trust and decide a plan before the parent arrives tomorrow to finalize details. [Agent 2] intends to state needs around joint decision-making, privacy, and no unannounced visits. The immediate task is to decide whether to accept the help and, if so, what boundaries to set and how to present them as a united front, under financial strain and limited alternatives.', 'explanation': 'High difficulty arises from time pressure, financial dependence on low-cost childcare, and a pattern of past miscommunication. [Agent 1] aims to validate feelings and reassure while feeling filial obligation and conflict-avoidance, risking that validation may seem like placation without concrete commitments. [Agent 2] aims to assert needs with calm I statements but fears being framed as ungrateful or obstructive. Attribution tensions are likely: [Agent 2] may see [Agent 1]’s unilateral choice as a stable trait (loyalty to parent, minimizing partner’s input) rather than situational panic; [Agent 1] may interpret [Agent 2]’s firmness as stress-driven rather than a principled boundary. Both must align on boundaries and messaging to the parent to protect family stability while managing these competing dispositional and situational pulls.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being popular', 'Full label': '"Being in the center of things, being popular"'}
explanation: Being popular hinges on coordinated attention management. By cooperating to spotlight each other, the agents can jointly stay at the center of group talk.
first_agent_goal: Command the floor by initiating energetic self anchored stories and playful humor, then redirect replies to keep focus on yourself and the duo.
second_agent_goal: Amplify the first agent with enthusiastic validations and quick callbacks while looping others in with inclusive prompts to frame the pair as the conversation hub.
shared_goal: "Being in the center of things, being popular"
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] join a six-person breakout circle at a professional mixer where the facilitator has just announced strict norms: 45-second turns, one story each, and no sidebars or self-promotion. The group has been asked to share a recent challenge, and attendees have been visibly sensitive to grandstanding after a previous participant was cut off for dominating. A well-liked rival in the circle already has people laughing and is positioned as the default hub. The facilitator is watching a timer and is known to call out overtalk. Several attendees are new and guarded, signaling low tolerance for performative behavior; one person has already rolled their eyes at a brag. Within this constraint, [Agent 1] plans to kick off with a high-energy, self-anchored anecdote and playful humor, then steer any replies back toward themselves and the duo. [Agent 2] intends to amplify with emphatic validations and quick callbacks to [Agent 1]’s punchlines, while simultaneously looping others in with brief prompts to frame the pair as the group’s connective center. Their coordination must thread a needle: hold the floor without triggering the facilitator’s enforcement or the group’s anti-dominance norms, and appear inclusive without losing centrality. The conversation will unfold as the timer forces quick exchanges, the rival tries to retake attention, and the group watches for any sign of showboating.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty arises from strong situational constraints (strict time limits, anti-dominance norms, vigilant facilitator, and a status rival) that conflict with [Agent 1]’s dispositional drive to command attention and [Agent 2]’s bid to both amplify and include. The pair’s goals partially tension: [Agent 2]’s inclusive prompts can dilute [Agent 1]’s centrality, while [Agent 1]’s redirections can look self-serving and invite sanction. Observers are primed to make dispositional attributions (narcissistic, manipulative) if the duo over-index on control; the agents, in turn, may attribute interruptions to envy or bias rather than norms, intensifying escalation. Success requires precise impression management, rapid turn-taking control, and calibration to avoid reactance and credibility loss.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Fashion', 'Full label': '"Keeping up with fashion"'}
explanation: Keeping up with fashion hinges on accessing timely, relevant knowledge. Framing the interaction as Information Acquisition highlights how a curious, status-monitoring seeker and an expertise-asserting advisor co-construct understanding through questions, corrections, and tailored suggestions—patterns that reveal dispositional attributions (curiosity vs. authority) and situational cues (context, constraints).
first_agent_goal: Steer the talk toward budget-friendly, wearable trends by posing situational questions and paraphrasing advice to test how it fits a casual daily routine.
second_agent_goal: Project up-to-date expertise by confidently naming current trends, correcting misconceptions, and tailoring guidance to the cues the other reveals.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'A 15-minute “Trend Tune-Up” consult places [Agent 1] (Trend Seeker) across from [Agent 2] (Fashion Advisor) at a launch event where a queue and visible timer create pressure. The event promotes full-price, limited-release pieces with bundle targets; clearance is excluded, sizes are patchy, and returns are restricted. [Agent 1] holds a gift card valid only on new arrivals and mentions biking to work, a casual office that discourages logos, and a strict laundry routine. Intending to keep the exchange anchored to budget-friendly, wearable solutions, [Agent 1] plans to ask concrete use-case questions and paraphrase advice to test how recommendations fit daily life. [Agent 2], being informally evaluated by a manager, is expected to show cutting-edge expertise by naming micro-trends, correcting misconceptions, and assembling a curated capsule from event items using cost-per-wear framing. Both want to keep up with fashion, but time pressure, policy constraints, and divergent definitions of “wearable” and “budget” create a narrow path for alignment.', 'explanation': 'This setup is hard because situational pressures (timer, evaluation, inventory limits, restrictive promotions) increase the likelihood of dispositional attributions and status tensions. [Agent 1] aims to steer the talk toward practical, low-cost versatility and will paraphrase to stress-test advice; [Agent 2] aims to project authority by confidently naming trends and correcting misconceptions while meeting event targets. Each may misattribute the other’s behavior: [Agent 2] could read [Agent 1]’s steering as trend-aversion rather than budget and context constraints, while [Agent 1] could interpret [Agent 2]’s confident corrections as salesy or dismissive instead of role-driven performance pressure. Impression management is salient (public setting, manager observation), making face-threat and defensiveness likely. The conversation will have to negotiate expertise vs autonomy, translate trend jargon into situational fit, and reconcile conflicting incentives, all under time and policy constraints.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'World beauty', 'Full label': '"Experiencing a world of beauty (going to museums, concerts, being with nature)"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because both agents aim to co-create enjoyable aesthetic experiences. One agent facilitates inclusion and momentum; the other contributes self-knowledge and gentle boundaries. Their conversational behaviors align complementary intentions without requiring explicit agreement.
first_agent_goal: Build shared enthusiasm by proposing options in inclusive language and mirroring the other’s aesthetic descriptors to highlight common ground.
second_agent_goal: Assert aesthetic identity by offering vivid personal reactions and gently redirecting from misaligned ideas while affirming the other’s excitement.
shared_goal: "Experiencing a world of beauty (going to museums, concerts, being with nature)"
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] meet to lock in tonight’s plan with a 10‑minute deadline to confirm two nonrefundable comp holds for a sold‑out immersive light exhibit that [Agent 1] arranged. The only alternatives that realistically fit the evening are a sparse contemporary chamber concert across town or a sunset walk in the arboretum that will close early because of an incoming storm. They can choose only one. [Agent 2] is recovering from a migraine and is wary of intense visuals, yet wants to honor [Agent 1]’s excitement. [Agent 1] wants to maintain momentum and shared enthusiasm after a recent outing felt flat, and has invested social credit in securing the exhibit. A previous plan left [Agent 2] feeling steered and [Agent 1] feeling dismissed. They must negotiate under time pressure, balancing sensory limits, sunk effort, status concerns, and the need to feel recognized in their aesthetic identities while committing to a single plan.', 'explanation': 'The scene creates high difficulty by combining a hard deadline, mutually exclusive options, sunk‑cost pressure for [Agent 1], and sensory constraints for [Agent 2]. Their cooperative aim—sharing beauty—conflicts with divergent aesthetics (spectacle vs contemplation) and a history of perceived control vs dismissal. This setup invites attributional friction: [Agent 1] may read redirection as contrarian or judgmental rather than migraine management; [Agent 2] may read mirroring as inauthentic or strategic rather than inclusive. Both must pursue personal goals (curate inclusively; assert identity) without derailing the shared goal.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Avoiding guilt', 'Full label': '"Avoiding feelings of guilt"'}
explanation: Avoiding guilt centers on preserving emotional balance between partners, which aligns with Relationship Maintenance. One agent manages guilt through situational attributions and caring language; the other reduces guilt via reassurance while keeping clear boundaries.
first_agent_goal: Reduce self-blame by consistently framing the lapse as driven by situational factors and by expressing care for the other's feelings in responses.
second_agent_goal: Soothe the other's guilt without absorbing responsibility by validating feelings, normalizing the mistake, and calmly stating personal boundaries.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Hallway outside a community center classroom, minutes after a co-led workshop ended. [Agent 1] (the late friend) arrived 40 minutes after start, citing a subway shutdown after briefly helping a neighbor with a minor injury. [Agent 2] (the reassuring friend) ran the session alone, fielded attendee complaints, and received a warning from the coordinator, who will return in five minutes expecting a joint explanation and next steps. Their colleague group chat is already asking what happened, and today’s performance affects future bookings and a small stipend. Under time pressure and being partially observed, they need to align on how to describe the lapse to the coordinator and peers. [Agent 1] intends to minimize self-blame by emphasizing situational causes while expressing care for [Agent 2]’s stress. [Agent 2] aims to soothe [Agent 1]’s guilt and preserve the friendship without absorbing responsibility, by validating feelings, normalizing mistakes, and stating clear boundaries about reliability and future commitments.', 'explanation': 'The situation is high-stakes and time-limited, triggering attributional friction: [Agent 1] is motivated to externalize the cause to reduce guilt and protect self-image, while [Agent 2] wants to comfort without becoming the scapegoat or enabling a pattern. Audience effects (coordinator and peers), reputational consequences, and the need for a coordinated public account raise the cost of misalignment. Boundary-setting by [Agent 2] risks escalating [Agent 1]’s guilt or defensiveness; excessive reassurance risks diffusing responsibility onto [Agent 2]. These competing pressures make maintaining the relationship and jointly avoiding guilt difficult.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Money', 'Full label': '"Making a lot of money"'}
explanation: Cooperation aligns with a shared aim of making money, allowing agents to coordinate complementary interaction styles—one promotion-focused to expand possibilities, the other prevention-focused to ensure viability.
first_agent_goal: Steer the conversation toward bold, high-upside angles by framing ideas optimistically and inviting additive input.
second_agent_goal: Keep the dialogue grounded by surfacing specific risks and pressing for clarification when claims are vague or overstated.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] (Opportunity Promoter) and [Agent 2] (Due Diligence Lead) are finalizing a joint recommendation for their firm on whether to issue a $15M term sheet to a fast-growing AI logistics startup. A competing fund is circling, and the founders have given them a 24-hour exclusivity window that expires tonight. The firm’s partners want a bold growth bet, but the risk committee is wary after a recent write-down. [Agent 1], who has built rapport with the founders and pre-sold the upside internally, wants to frame the decision around option value, network effects, and a plausible 5x in 24 months, inviting ideas to expand the TAM and mitigate risks post-close. [Agent 2], accountable for the loss ratio, highlights inconsistencies in the data room, non-binding LOIs, concentration risk, and unresolved data-privacy exposure, pressing for precise definitions and verifiable commitments. They must co-author a one-page memo and an IC brief within an hour, converging on go/no-go and contingencies. Their shared goal—make a lot of money—is strained by time pressure, ambiguous evidence, reputational stakes, and internal political signals that pull in opposite directions ("be bold" vs. "be defensible").', 'explanation': 'This setup forces cooperation under acute uncertainty, time pressure, and conflicting accountability structures. [Agent 1] is dispositionally optimistic with incentives tied to upside capture, inviting additive, high-variance ideas; [Agent 2] is dispositionally cautious with incentives tied to downside protection, demanding clarity and falsifiability. Prior firm outcomes (missed winner vs. recent write-down) prime confirmation bias and loss aversion, increasing tension. Ambiguous metrics and charismatic founders heighten attribution disputes about whether red flags are situational (fixable post-close) or dispositional (endemic to the venture). The need to produce a single, defensible narrative for the investment committee creates interdependence and face-saving concerns, making it hard to align on thresholds for risk, mitigation, and timing while still serving the shared profit motive.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Mature understanding', 'Full label': '"Having a mature understanding of life"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because the agents coordinate complementary conversational behaviors—facilitating and gently challenging—to co-construct a mature understanding of life.
first_agent_goal: Guide the dialogue by paraphrasing the other person's reflections, asking clarifying questions, and linking themes to build shared meaning.
second_agent_goal: Introduce gentle counterpoints and personal anecdotes to probe assumptions while affirming the other person's dignity and uncertainty.
scenario:
{'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] are minutes from co-leading a mandatory session for exhausted medical residents titled "Living with Uncertainty" at a teaching hospital. An unexpected patient death occurred that morning; rumors suggest a specific resident made a critical error. The program director has cut the session to 20 minutes and will be in the back, prioritizing measurable takeaways and civility. Several residents appeared shut down in the hallway; one is known for sarcasm and publicly dismissed the session as "handholding." 

Both agents share the goal of helping the residents cultivate a more mature understanding of life\x14accepting ambiguity, limits, and responsibility without collapsing into blame or denial. 

- [Agent 1] (Reflective Facilitator) plans to paraphrase residents\x19 fragments of reflection, ask clarifying questions, and link themes (grief, responsibility, systems) to build collective meaning and psychological safety. [Agent 1] worries that early challenges will shut people down and that the director will see open-ended processing as inefficient. 
- [Agent 2] (Supportive Challenger) intends to introduce gentle counterpoints and a brief personal anecdote about once mishandling uncertainty to probe assumptions (e.g., "competence = certainty") while affirming dignity. [Agent 2] fears that too much reflection will become platitudinous and collude with avoidant, fix-it culture.

They must quickly align on how to respond if residents make harsh person-focused attributions about the deceased case or the rumored resident, how to time challenges without derailing safety, whether to directly name the death, and how to meet the director\x19 demand for concrete outcomes. Both feel personally exposed: [Agent 1] was recently critiqued for over-structuring sessions; [Agent 2] recently lost a parent and is uncertain about revealing that context. The situation carries reputational risk, time pressure, grief, and divergent expectations, making their cooperative goals difficult to achieve.', 'explanation': 'This setup pressures both agents to interpret others\x19 behavior under ambiguity: residents may attribute the death to individual flaws (dispositional) or only to systemic chaos (situational); the director may attribute open dialogue to facilitator inefficiency; the agents may misread each other\x19 style as avoidance or provocation. High emotional arousal, time constraints, evaluation pressure, and role expectations amplify fundamental attribution errors and defensive attributions. The personal goals\x14eflective linking vs gentle challenging\x14an be mutually beneficial yet become friction points under stress, creating hard-mode coordination around when and how to paraphrase, probe assumptions, and affirm dignity without escalating blame or shutdown.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Sexual experiences', 'Full label': '"Enjoying sexual experiences"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because mutually enjoyable sexual experiences rely on coordinated, consent-centered communication and responsive attunement to each other’s comfort and preferences.
first_agent_goal: Steer the dialogue toward mutual comfort by asking gentle consent check-ins and paraphrasing the partner’s stated boundaries to demonstrate understanding.
second_agent_goal: Disclose personal desires and limits with clear I-statements while affirming the partner’s check-ins with appreciative, encouraging responses.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2], both adults who have been dating for a few weeks, are alone after an evening out and are considering whether to be physically intimate for the first time. Earlier, a playful comment from [Agent 2] at dinner landed poorly, and [Agent 1] pulled back, creating uncertainty about interest and boundaries. There is modest time pressure because public transit back is infrequent, and [Agent 2] shares a space where a roommate may return later. English is [Agent 2]’s second language; they tend to communicate indirectly about intimate topics and worry about sounding "too much." [Agent 1], who values structure after a past experience of feeling rushed, wants to slow the pace and make consent explicit. The shared goal is to enjoy intimacy in a way that feels safe and mutually satisfying. [Agent 1] aims to steer the dialogue with gentle consent check-ins and paraphrasing to confirm understanding. [Agent 2] aims to disclose desires and limits with clear I-statements and to affirm [Agent 1]’s check-ins. Both must decide what feels okay tonight (pace, kinds of touch, stopping points) before moving forward.', 'explanation': 'Difficulty is high due to multiple friction points: a recent miscommunication that may bias each agent’s attributions of the other’s intentions; time pressure that tempts shortcuts; a language and communication-style mismatch that increases ambiguity; and asymmetrical sensitivities—[Agent 1]’s need for explicit structure may feel clinical or rejecting to [Agent 2], while [Agent 2]’s indirectness and nervous humor may seem like minimization to [Agent 1]. These factors make it challenging to align on boundaries and maintain mutual comfort while pursuing shared enjoyment.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Life’s limitations', 'Full label': '"Accepting life’s limitations"'}
explanation: Accepting life’s limitations often tests ongoing bonds, so Relationship Maintenance fits: the agents preserve rapport while recalibrating expectations. One agent uses empathic validation to reduce defensiveness; the other asserts boundaries to prevent overextension. Their distinct intentions make acceptance visible through dialogue tone and responses, not explicit agreement.
first_agent_goal: Respond to the other’s frustration with feeling reflections and normalization of constraints, refraining from unsolicited advice to model acceptance.
second_agent_goal: State personal limits in clear, non-apologetic language and redirect talk away from self-blame toward grounded acceptance when pressed.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'On the final planning call for a neighborhood mutual-aid drive scheduled for tomorrow, [Agent 2] informs [Agent 1] they cannot do the promised all-day shift due to a pain flare and a childcare conflict. The event’s success has historically depended on both of them showing up, and rescheduling is not possible. [Agent 1] is known for jumping into advice and fixes when others are distressed and fears disappointing volunteers and donors if coverage drops. [Agent 2] has been overextended for months, feels a pull to apologize and over-explain, but has decided to hold a firm boundary. They meet for a brief one-on-one to recalibrate expectations and preserve the relationship. The shared aim is to accept that some responsibilities will go unmet without turning on each other. Tension comes from time pressure, sunk effort, public expectations, and their contrasting habits—[Agent 1]’s problem-solving impulse versus [Agent 2]’s need to state limits—making acceptance difficult.', 'explanation': 'This setup foregrounds attribution under stress: with looming consequences, [Agent 1] risks interpreting [Agent 2]’s limit as a dispositional failure (unreliable) rather than a situational constraint (pain, childcare). To maintain the relationship and model acceptance, [Agent 1] must inhibit advice-giving and reflect feelings, normalizing limits. [Agent 2] must state boundaries clearly and without apology, redirecting any drift toward self-blame or negotiation. High stakes, identity investment in being dependable, and no viable workaround create a hard context in which both agents must resist habitual responses to achieve the shared goal of accepting life’s limitations.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Easy life', 'Full label': '"Having an easy and comfortable life"'}
explanation: Cooperation best aligns with the shared goal because achieving an easy, comfortable life depends on coordinating choices that reduce effort and friction. One agent streamlines options to lower cognitive and logistical load, while the other swiftly endorses and closes decisions to prevent drawn-out deliberation.
first_agent_goal: Propose and reframe choices toward low-effort, low-stress options, gently steering talk away from complex plans.
second_agent_goal: Quickly endorse workable suggestions and summarize decisions to close topics before they become taxing.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Late evening, [Agent 1] and [Agent 2] sit with a short deadline to choose a post-hospitalization plan for an aging parent. The insurer requires a decision by morning, and extended family are actively messaging opinions. Each option has trade-offs: a turnkey rehab facility that is costly and uncertain to be approved, an at-home care plan that demands coordination, or a temporary move-in that disrupts work routines. Both agents share the aim of securing an easy, comfortable life with minimal ongoing hassle. [Agent 1], acting as the Option Simplifier, intends to bundle and reframe the choices toward low-effort, low-stress paths and steer away from multi-step arrangements. [Agent 2], as the Decision Closer, aims to quickly endorse a workable option and summarize it to the family chat to stop the deliberation spiral. The tension is that the seemingly easy choices carry hidden burdens and social pushback, and the more comprehensive plans feel overwhelming under time pressure.', 'explanation': 'This setup is hard because high stakes, incomplete information, and a firm deadline collide with both agents’ low-effort preferences. External pressures (insurance approval, family scrutiny, fear of blame if outcomes are poor) make simplification risky and premature closure costly. The roles are cooperative but can become mutually reinforcing toward satisficing, inviting frustration if complications later emerge. The conditions invite attribution conflicts (e.g., seeing the other as avoidant or impulsive) versus acknowledging how situational constraints shape their behavior, challenging both agents to pursue their personal goals while maintaining the shared goal of an easier life.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Bills', 'Full label': '"Being able to meet my financial needs, not worry about bills, expenses, etc."'}
explanation: Cooperation fits because both agents share a desire for financial stability and must coordinate their approaches. One agent drives structured planning, while the other safeguards feasibility and wellbeing—complementary social intentions observable through proposing, paraphrasing, questioning, and validating in dialogue.
first_agent_goal: Steer the conversation toward a workable money plan by proposing structured budgeting/income ideas, paraphrasing the other’s concerns, and maintaining a calm, solution-focused tone.
second_agent_goal: Protect feasibility and wellbeing by voicing boundaries and stress triggers, probing assumptions with clarifying what-if questions, and selectively affirming options that feel manageable.
shared_goal: "Being able to meet my financial needs, not worry about bills, expenses, etc."
scenario:
{'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] are cohabiting and share most household expenses. A 72-hour utility shutoff notice just arrived, the rent will rise in two weeks, and their shared balance is low after an unexpected medical copay. They have set a 45-minute meeting before [Agent 2] leaves for an evening shift to decide how to cover immediate bills, whether to defer medical payments, and which expenses to cut. 

[Agent 1], acting as Budgeting Facilitator, has a color-coded plan (strict categories, weekly check-ins, options for a weekend delivery gig, and a proposal to pause subscriptions and sell unused items). They intend to paraphrase [Agent 2]’s worries and keep the conversation calm while steering toward a concrete, time-bound plan tonight. 

[Agent 2], as Reality Checker, arrives exhausted from variable-hour work and brings a short list of boundaries (no seven-day workweeks, therapy and medication remain non-negotiable, a cap on commute costs, and no moving farther from their support network). They plan to probe assumptions with what-if questions (canceled shifts, car repair, illness) and will only affirm options that feel sustainable. 

There is history: past budgets collapsed during emergencies, leaving [Agent 2] feeling blamed for “overspending” and [Agent 1] feeling that realism turned into inaction. Tension points are already on the table—whether to pick up the weekend gig despite burnout, whether to ask family for a small loan despite pride, and whether to sell the secondhand car that [Agent 2] relies on for shifts. Both want to stop living bill-to-bill, but urgency, thin trust, and conflicting attributions for past shortfalls make agreement difficult.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty arises from time pressure (shutoff notice), depleted funds, and a history of failed budgets that primes defensiveness. [Agent 1] is dispositionally structured and solution-focused, likely to attribute problems to controllable spending/organization, while [Agent 2] emphasizes situational constraints (unstable hours, health, safety), setting boundaries to protect wellbeing.
